properties.Name: St. Magnus's Church (In Ruins)
properties.Authorities for spelling:
Mr James Goudie Schoolmaster
Mr T B Reid, Sourin
Mr Craigie, Mugly
properties.Description remarks:
This name applies to the ruins of a church situate about the centre of Egilshay It is said Magnus Erlendson (St Magnus was murdered (16th Aptil 1115) in it, or near the place where it stands by his cousin Paul. [Continued]
The building is of great antiquity having been erected it is thought prior to the 9th century, but is in an excellent state of preservation, its lofty steeple forming a prominent landmark. The Grave Yard in which the ruins are is still used for interments.
properties.Extras:
[page] 179
Parish of Rousay -- Orkney Isles Transcriber's notes Note below Place entry for St Magnus's Church: (O.E.) [Old English]

Note at foot of page: Over [page] 180

Note next to description of St Magnus's Church:
Egilshay is famed for its ancient cathedral now in ruins, known by the name of St. Magnus Church, which is in a good state of preservation. The date of its erection is unknown: but it is supposed to have been long prior to mediaeval times. It is the oldest building now extant in Orkney. It derived its name from the tradition that Magnus, one of the Earls of Orkney, was murdered in or near the place where is stands, about 1110." - Anderson's Orkney Directory.

Note at foot of page: The whole of the above are on the property of Dr. [Doctor] Baikie Tankerness.

Note next to description of St Magnus's Church:
Egilshay is famed for its ancient cathedral now in ruins, known by the name of St. Magnus Church, which is in a good state of preservation. The date of its erection is unknown: but it is supposed to have been long prior to mediaeval times. It is the oldest building now extant in Orkney. It derived its name from the tradition that Magnus, one of the Earls of Orkney, was murdered in or near the place where is stands, about 1110." - Anderson's Orkney Directory.

Note at foot of page: The whole of the above are on the property of Dr. [Doctor] Baikie Tankerness.

Applies to public school for boy & girls situate on the west side of public road about 2 1/4 miles NE from "Trumbland House" & 35 ch SE from free "Church" in the district of Sourin.
Erected in 1875, built of stone slated & in good repair, with substantial two story house,attached, for the teacher. This school will accommodate 60 children, daily average for the last 12 months - Supported by School Board Authorities for the Parish of Rousay.

properties.Description remarks: This name applies to a channel situated between Burgar & Enhallow Island "Eynhallow Sound" separating the island of Rowsa from Mainland is 7 miles long and 3/4 mile wise at its narrowest part. The islands Rowsa and Wyre are upon its northeast side; Mainland is to the southwest; the small island Eynhallow lies a little within the entrance and near to mid-channel; while the island of Gairsay terminated the sound and divides it from Widefirth. North Sea Pilot

properties.Name: Rousay [Parish]
properties.Authorities for spelling:
Rev James Gardner Sourin
Rev Alexander Allardice Bringan
Mr Reid Poor Inspector Colonel Burroughs C.B. Rousay by Kirkwall
John A. Bruce Esq [esquire] Sheriff Clerk Kirkwall
Handbook to the Orkneys Peace's County Directory
Orkney & Shetland Guide & Directory
properties.Description remarks: A parish on the North Isles of Orkney. It comprehends the inhabited islands of Eynhallow, Egilsay & Viera and a few uninhabited islands. The parish is in the presbytery of North Isles and Synod of Orkney. It contains a post office station of its own name. It lies parallel to the district of Evie in the extreme northwest of the mainland, and is separated from it by Eynhallow Sound. It has Egilsay along its east side at the distance of about 3/4 of a mile. It is bounded on the north by Saviskaill Bay & Westray Firth & on the west by the Atlantic Ocean. There is no detached part of this parish locally situated within the boundary of any other parish nor is there any detached part of any other, locally situated within the boundary of this one. It contains about 14,749 statute acres.

properties.Name: Site Of Chapel [Island In Loch Of Wasbister]
properties.List of names as written: Site of CHAPEL [island in Loch of Wasbister]
properties.Authorities for spelling:
Mr. William Seatter, Saviskaill.
Mr. Gibson, Langskaill.
Hugh Craigie.
properties.Description remarks:
Applies to a small island situate in the Lock of Wasbister. It contains the site of an ancient chapel and was formerly connected with the mainland with stepping stones which are still visible under the surface of the loch. From the fact of deer horns, bones, coins etc. having been found on the site of the old chapel it is thought that a more ancient building existed there prior to the erection of the chapel.
Col. Burrough proprietor
